thank you for coming to my ted talk (“pharma rep territories influence regional variations in prescribing & drug utilization”) disclosure: in the before times, i spent 16+ years as a field sales rep for suboxone, oxycontin, & other brand medications.

even 1 “high decile” prescriber rxing for a chronic illness, &/or medication that causes physical dependence, will cause a regional spike in rx refills. pharma reps are *directly incentivized* to “grow” prescribing! add drug reps to map correlation w/geographic rx variation

what makes certain prescribers “influential” re: regional rx data? a) if a speaker/trainer/“thoughtleader” for pharma brand- they directly influence peers to rx more. they usually speak/teach the most locally. b) they initiate new rxs-then pts move to other local practices.

when i see studies on geographical differences in prescribing, a variable rarely included is: 1) of pharma sales reps (promoting that class of medication). yes, this is hard to study (proprietary data) but closely impacts a 2nd variable: 2) influential high prescribers.

most people use illicit buprenorphine to “treat” withdrawal & a much smaller use it for euphoria.(hard to achieve w/repeated exposure.) while illicit /=/ “treatment” it’s harmreduction re: overdose mortality. jails/prisons *must* provide oud meds! publichealth research

drop links to this   2018 article to address all the myths, tropes, & mistakes about addiction, racist drug policy, opioid rxs, misuse & opioid use disorder. and it’s in plain language, not jargon. ”what the media gets wrong about opioids”

favorite irises: this lovely yellow tall bearded iris gets heavy & needs staking, but reblooms consistently spring & fall! it’s a winner. planted years ago- recently found the tag, it’s called “harvest of memories.”

but the scourge of our perennial beds are two invasive flowers- chrysanthemum (foliage on left) & ground elder/bishop’s weed (white bloom on right.) ugh, whyyyy?! tons of hand weeding this year as they spring up in the middle of other flowers, but they come right back

caution! solomon’s seal works in shade, w/attractive variagated foliage, even when the tiny white flowers aren’t blooming. but it is *invasive* in good soil conditions & has muscled out neighboring flowers . (want some for free?! come visit me.) flowerreport perennialregrets
